```java
String str = "Hello, World!";
byte[] byteArray = str.getBytes();
```

In this example, the getBytes() method is used to convert the String "Hello, World!" into a byte array. The byte array will contain the binary representation of the characters in the string.

If you want to specify the character encoding, you can do so by passing the name of the encoding to the getBytes() method. For example, to convert the string to a byte array using UTF-8 encoding, you can do:

```java
String str = "Hello, World!";
byte[] byteArray = str.getBytes("UTF-8");
```

In this case, the getBytes() method will use UTF-8 encoding to convert the string into a byte array.

Please note that the getBytes() method can throw a UnsupportedEncodingException if the named charset is not supported. So, you should handle this exception properly in your code.

Also, if you want to convert a byte array back to a String, you can use the String constructor that takes a byte array and a charset name. For example:

```java
byte[] byteArray = "Hello, World!".getBytes();
String str = new String(byteArray, "UTF-8");
```
